text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with spring lamb sliders that's
right we're calling this video spring
lamb sliders because that's eventually
what we're going to do with the meat we
cook but with this video's really about
is how to cook a lamb shoulder which is
one of my favorite cuts and I believe
generally preferable to the more popular
leg of lamb which tends to be more
expensive and not as user friendly you
remember the time you bought that
expensive leg lamb and then overcooked
it and your guests lied and said they
liked it but you can see it in their eye
so if you've had that experience pay
attention because I think this is a
great and very delicious alternative so
let's go ahead get started with the
aforementioned lamb shoulder and I have
about a three and a half pound roast
here bone-in in fact really bone-in we
got all kinds of bones here we got an
arm bone we got a shoulder blade we got
ribs heck we even have some vertebrae
but don't worry there's also tons of
meat an amazing succulent meat at that
and what we want to do first is season
this up very generously with some kosher
salt and freshly ground black pepper
both sides of course and any exposed
surfaces and by the way to answer a
viewer email yes after I turn the camera
off on these seasoning shots I always go
back over and season the spots I missed
so thanks for asking so we will
thoughtfully season both sides with salt
and pepper
at which point we're going to head over
to the stove and brown this over high
heat and Dutch oven and a little bit of
vegetable oil so we will start with our
meat side down bone side up and we will
see that side very well for about four
or five minutes before flipping it over
and right here you get a pretty good
look at what we're going for so a
beautiful golden-brown crust and as you
can see that sides going to sear pretty
nicely because of the fat and more
importantly it's a flat surface but that
bone side not so much but regardless
we'll just let that second side cook for
about four or five minutes and while it
does I like to add my roughly chopped
onions and garlic and just sort of
situate that vegetation in and around my
lamb and what will happen while we're
giving that bone side a little bit of a
sear those onions are going to soften up
a little bit and yeah start to turn
translucent so we'll add those in and
give a little stir once a while and at
this point we go ahead and add the rest
of the ingredients which because lamb
shoulder is so flavorful is only a
couple things so we will add some
chicken broth or stock or I guess water
if times are tough
and then because I'm going for a little
bit of a sweet-and-sour thing here I'm
going to go ahead and add in some apple
cider vinegar as well as some honey and
I'll be using a light amber honey this
time which you may remember from such
videos as to Rhoni and then besides the
honey I'm going to finish this up with a
little bit of red chili flake you know I
like a little bit of heat with my sweet
and then we'll just make sure all that
stuff's mixed together so I stirred that
together using my lamb roast is like a
giant meat spatula which while
awkward-looking works surprisingly well
and then what we'll do once that's all
mixed and please pay attention because
this is very complicated
we're going to pop on the lid and put
this in the center of a 325 degree oven
for approximately three hours or until
the meats fork tender that's it
I'm not kidding it's that easy and about
three hours later if everything's gone
according to plan your lamb shoulder
should look something like this and I
did say fork tender but I could have
said blade tender because if you could
tug at that shoulder blade and it comes
out clean like this you know your meat
is done but because I did say fork
tender let's give it the old poka poka
just for an extra visual and as you can
see that meat is ready to eat so at this
point if you are going to use this for
sliders and you certainly don't have to
but if you are we're going to want to do
a couple things we're going to want to
spoon off any excess fat which a lamb
shoulder is going to produce a fair
amount of and of course we're also going
to have to pull the meat apart and add
it back to those pan drippings and it's
totally cool if you do this while it's
warm but I didn't and usually don't I
like to do this the day before and let
it chill overnight and pull it out the
next day and work with it while it's
cold and one advantage to this is you
can easily kind of flake that fat off
the top which does make it kind of easy
to remove but also I think it's just
easier breaking up the meat when it's
cold but anyway no matter whether you're
working with this warm or cold the next
day what we will do is break that up
into a saucepan of course we're moving
all those bones and or other inedible
parts and then what we'll do is we'll
place that meat on the stove and put it
on medium heat and we will add those
amazingly flavorful pan drippings back
in and I do do the extra step of heating
it and straining it in every once a
while you might get a little fragment of
bone that will fall off and you'll miss
it picking the meat
or a giant bomb like that one I mean
once we have our pick needs and
associated juices in that saucepan we
will simply heat that through over a
medium flame and other than adding a
little bit of fresh mint and adjusting
the seasonings that's pretty much it so
we will give that an occasional stir
while it heats up and once it comes back
to temperature and start simmering I'm
going to finish this off with a nice big
pinch of freshly sliced mint leaves or
is your food bloggers friend might call
it chiffonade of mint so we'll stir that
in and I think we're done although we
better taste for seasoning and don't be
surprised if it needs a little more salt
and then once that is seasoned to our
liking we can go ahead and serve that up
in my case on a slider roll that I
toasted in some olive oil and we will
pile that glorious meat up nice and high
don't worry if it's overflowing that's
fine it's alright if a little bit falls
out unless you have to take pictures so
I will have to clean that up between
shots which I did
so I tidied that up and decided to
finish with some chili flakes which I
also will be cleaning up and then last
but not least a little touch of extra
fresh mint and we will place on the top
and impel it with the obligatory
and possibly gratuitous slider skewer
and that's it our spring lamb slider is
done and I was going to say looks
amazing
but you know what if we're being honest
pulled meat never really looks that
awesome but man does it usually taste
awesome and this certainly did with a
little bit of sweetness from the honey
and a little bit of tankiness from the
vinegar and of course we also have a
little bit of heat from the chili flakes
not to mention that sweet herbaceousness
from the mint so just incredibly tasty
bite of food I'm going to have another
bite as soon as I cleanse my palate with
a prop chip and you should have plenty
of amazing juices so don't be afraid
while you're eating a spoon a little
more on and while that shot was out of
focus the effect was in credible I mean
it's kind of loosey kind of juicy and
yet it will stay together fairly nicely
as you're eating this so I just
absolutely loved how this came out oh
and by the way in case you're wondering
that's a sliced watermelon radish which
really does look like what it's named
for especially if you sprinkle on a few
black sesame seeds and they actually
taste pretty good I mean not as good as
meat but pretty good so whether you are
making this for the holiday
or March Madness viewing party or any
time you want rich delicious succulent
meat I really do hope you give this a
try so head over to food wishes calm for
all the ingredient amounts and more info
as usual and as always enjoy
